title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a pilot program on dog training therapy within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms in veterans with disabilities. The program will run for three to five years at selected VA medical centers, providing training for veterans with mental health conditions. The pilot program aims to educate veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. It includes dedicated indoor space for grooming and training, wheelchair accessibility, classroom space, office space, equipment storage, outdoor exercise area for dogs, and transportation for field trips. The program will be administered through Recreation Therapy. The pilot program will be administered through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs. It will include certified service dog training instructors at each site and a director of service dog training with specific qualifications. The pilot program administered by the Department of Veterans Affairs includes selecting assistance dogs from shelters or foster homes, ensuring dogs have proper temperament and health clearances, teaching essential commands to service dogs in training, housing them at the program site or nearby foster homes, providing both theoretical and practical training in service dog skills, and maximizing therapeutic benefits for veterans. The pilot program aims to maximize therapeutic benefits for veterans with disabilities by providing well-trained service dogs. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental health conditions can volunteer if resources are available. Hiring preference for service dog training instructors is given to veterans who have graduated from treatment programs. The Secretary will collect data on the pilot program to assess its effectiveness for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental health conditions. Data will include outcomes such as reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, community reintegration, and reducing social isolation through exposure to new environments with the service dogs. The pilot program aims to help veterans with mental health conditions by reducing social isolation, building relationship skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and decreasing pain medication use. The Secretary will report to Congress annually on the program's effectiveness, including the number of participants and services provided. The pilot program aims to help veterans with mental health conditions by addressing symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, family dynamics, insomnia, pain management, and overall well-being. The Secretary will provide recommendations on extending or expanding the program. The pilot program aims to train veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder and other post-deployment issues in service dog training.
